title: 106_hr5177
content: The Act may be cited as the "Administrative Law Judge Conference of the United States Act". The Congress establishes the Administrative Law Judge Conference of the United States to enhance efficiency, productivity, and public trust in resolving disputes. This conference aims to improve the system of agency assignments for administrative law judges and enhance judicial performance and status. States will improve judicial performance and legal training of administrative law judges through education programs and system studies, reporting to Congress annually. The Administrative Law Judge Conference of the United States is established under Chapter 5 of title 5, United States Code. The Administrative Law Judge Conference of the United States is defined in Section 597 as consisting of all administrative law judges appointed under Section 599A. The chief administrative law judge is appointed under Section 599. The chief administrative law judge is appointed by the President with Senate approval, must have served as an administrative law judge for at least 5 years, and serves a 5-year term. The chief judge can be reappointed for one additional term. The chief judge's pay is at 105 percent of basic pay for level IV of the Executive Schedule. The chief judge has powers to enhance and develop the administrative law process. The chief administrative law judge is appointed by the President with Senate approval, must have served as an administrative law judge for at least 5 years, and serves a 5-year term. The chief judge can be reappointed for one additional term and has powers to enhance and develop the administrative law process. The chief judge's responsibilities include developing training programs for administrative law judges, consulting with agencies on necessary resources, studying instances of nonacquiescence by agencies, and making rules to implement the functions of the Conference. The chief judge of the Conference reports annually to the President and Congress with recommendations for improving the adjudicative process. The Office of Personnel Management's functions regarding administrative law judges are transferred to the Conference. Administrative law judges are assigned to agencies by the chief judge for case adjudication. Sec. 599B. Jurisdiction: Courts can refer cases to administrative law judges with agency approval. Administrative law judges are appointed by agencies and provided with necessary resources. The referring court retains jurisdiction over cases referred to administrative law judges, with de novo review of the judge's recommendations. The agency is reimbursed for costs related to the referral. The subchapter does not affect agency rulemaking authority, the adjudicatory authority of administrative law judges, or an agency's authority to review decisions of administrative law judges. The chief judge establishes rules of conduct for administrative law judges, based on the Model Code of Judicial Conduct. Removal or discipline of judges is only allowed as specified in section 7521. Compliance with the rules satisfies procedural requirements under title 5 of the United States Code. Authorization of $5,000,000 for the Administrative Law Judge Conference of the United States in fiscal year 2000. Amend the table of sections for chapter 5 of title 5, United States Code. The Administrative Law Judge Conference of the United States is defined, established, and includes provisions for membership, the chief administrative law judge, administrative law judges, jurisdiction, and standards of conduct. Transition provisions are also outlined. Transfers of personnel, property, and funds to the Administrative Law Judge Conference of the United States from the Office of Personnel Management. Collective bargaining agreements for transferred personnel remain in effect. Disputes to be handled by the Director of the Office of Management and Budget. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will resolve any disputes related to personnel or asset transfers as needed. The Administrative Law Judge Conference of the United States will begin operating when the first chief judge takes office. This Act and its amendments will take effect 120 days after enactment.
